title: Bootnode command not working
body:
#### System information

Geth version:  1.5.9-stable
OS & Version: Linux/Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS (x86_64)

#### Expected behaviour
I want to be able to generate a bootnode key `bootnode -genkey bootnode.key`

#### Actual behaviour
When running `bootnode` in the system console I get a `bootnode: command not found` after having installed ethereum as suggested [here](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/wiki/Installation-Instructions-for-Ubuntu). Either the `bootnode` command is not being shipped with the ethereum package installation or I am missing something.

Hmm, `bootnode` is indeed not packaged according to https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/build/ci.go#L70

@fjl ?

Hello again, I would appreciate if someone could help me with a scenario affected by this issue ([Ethereum Stack Exchange](http://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/12444/adding-nodes-in-private-network-of-docker-containers-hosted-in-different-vms)).

We'll bundle the bootnode to into the alltools archive (and inherently the deb packages). https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/3735

I'll merge after the CI is green.

Bootnode should now be part of the PPAs. 

Btw, this is a more up to date installation guide https://geth.ethereum.org/install/
(the develop PPAs that is. it will ship in the next stable release of geth into the stable ones)

Hi again @karalabe 
I am running 
```
sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:ethereum/ethereum
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install ethereum-unstable
```
but when I see what is being downloaded :
```
After this operation, 48.6 MB of additional disk space will be used.
Get:1 http://ppa.launchpad.net/ethereum/ethereum/ubuntu xenial/main amd64 abigen-unstable amd64 1.6.0+build9136+xenial [1420 kB]
Get:2 http://ppa.launchpad.net/ethereum/ethereum/ubuntu xenial/main amd64 geth-unstable amd64 1.6.0+build9136+xenial [4566 kB]
Get:3 http://ppa.launchpad.net/ethereum/ethereum/ubuntu xenial/main amd64 rlpdump-unstable amd64 1.6.0+build9136+xenial [521 kB]
Get:4 http://ppa.launchpad.net/ethereum/ethereum/ubuntu xenial/main amd64 evm-unstable amd64 1.6.0+build9136+xenial [2702 kB]
Get:5 http://ppa.launchpad.net/ethereum/ethereum/ubuntu xenial/main amd64 swarm-unstable amd64 1.6.0+build9136+xenial [3622 kB]
Get:6 http://ppa.launchpad.net/ethereum/ethereum/ubuntu xenial/main amd64 ethereum-unstable amd64 1.6.0+build9136+xenial [1550 B]
```
I cant find the "bootnode" either...
Bleah, I added it to the archives but the Ubuntu PPAs were done form a different list. Opened a PR to fix that too. Let me get an ack from someone and I'll merge it in.

Also, I am trying to use Docker for the project I am working on. Although I am using `FROM ethereum/client-go:develop` neither `geth` nor `bootnode` are recognized in my entrypoint executable file. Any ideas why this might be? This is why I am running a RUN instruction that performs the sudo apt repository / update / install. inside my Dockerfile.
The [docker container](https://hub.docker.com/r/ethereum/client-go/~/dockerfile/) only contains Geth itself in the system root `/geth` in order to make it as slim as possible.

Thanks, now its working. 
I did notice that `/geth` did work. Is it still possible to get only the bootnode command from the `apt-get` instruction on the `ethereum-unstable`?

~~Doing `apt-get install bootnode-unstable` should work.~~

Ah no, because it's a single package. No, I don't think so then.

having written
```
sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:ethereum/ethereum
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install bootnode
```
The output in the console is the following:
```
Package bootnode is not available, but is referred to by another package.
This may mean that the package is missing, has been obsoleted, or
is only available from another source

E: Package 'bootnode' has no installation candidate
```
Yes, I also figured it won't work. The only way is to download the package and extract that single file. Or install the package, copy out the bootnode and then uninstall the package.

By the way (sorry for bringing so many issues), could you take a look at this: [Unreachable bootnode](http://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/12515/node-discovery-unreachable-bootnode-in-private-distributed-network). It's about node discovery. I cant get it to work and I am not sure if it has something to do with the fact that the port is not responding to `telnet` command
I am also having the same issue, is it solved yet?
bootnode command not found for homebrew installation for macOS Sierra. Is it only available to Ubuntu?
Likewise, I'm having the same issue, and the linked docs that @karalabe put above (https://geth.ethereum.org/install/) has no directions for macOS.
try building geth from source from https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/wiki/Installation-Instructions-for-Mac instead of homebrew
@terencecnt I ran into the same issue with homebrew installation. I submitted https://github.com/ethereum/homebrew-ethereum/pull/114 to add `bootnode` to the homebrew install

@karalabe  Sir, how to get it working on wwindows any idea ??

i got bootnode working on mac by:
```
brew install ethereum --devel
cd /Users/milean/Library/Caches/Homebrew/ethereum--git
make all
```
then the 'bootnode' command appeared in 
/Users/milean/Library/Caches/Homebrew/ethereum--git/build/bin/bootnode

i faced the same issue.
bootnode : command not found

need some help

Upon installation use `sudo apt-get install ethereum` as described here https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/wiki/Installation-Instructions-for-Ubuntu

> You can alternatively install only the `geth` CLI with `apt-get install geth` if you don't want to install the other utilities (`bootnode`, `evm`, `disasm`, `rlpdump`, `ethtest`).

I got `bootnode` working on Ubuntu by:

```
sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:ethereum/ethereum
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install bootnode
```

> I got `bootnode` working on Ubuntu by:
> 
> ```
> sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:ethereum/ethereum
> sudo apt-get update
> sudo apt-get install bootnode
> ```

This is great. Thanks it worked for me as well.
